AAC seems to be happy with the initial KPIs they are seeing and will need to monitor how the ICAP metric develops over time.
  • We did not have the time to analyse in detail how AAC’s services influence people’s donations.
  • Due to a lack of data, we could not understand the outcomes and impact of AAC’s career advice resources, earning to give programme, and the inclusive hiring skills workshops.

Overall, the evaluation evidence demonstrates that AAC has counterfactually caused people to change career paths and assume roles within the movement. This positively updates us on assumptions #10 (founding of new organisations), 11 (strong career paths in related areas), 13 (strong career paths and capabilities for work in the movement), 14 (increased awareness of opportunities), and 15 (influx of talent to the movement). The evidence on assumption #12 (increased donations and funding) is less strong, given that we have seen evidence of increased funding as a result of the fundraising programme but have not had the time to analyse the effect of AAC’s services on people’s donations and the earning to give programme is still in its early stages. We could also not update our uncertainty around assumption #16 (improved hiring practices at organisations) due to a lack of evaluation data for the workshops. Assumptions #17 to 21 were not investigated in detail due to our low uncertainty around them and the absence of relevant data.

3.2  External evidence not collected by organisation

Apart from the evidence that AAC has collected internally, we also need to look at external pieces of evidence that can inform our opinion about the kinds of programmes AAC is running and how likely their ToC is to hold. We specifically took the following steps in order to broaden our perspective on AAC’s work and reduce key uncertainties.

  1. We did a quick, time-capped literature review on assumption #13 in our ToC, as it is one of the most crucial breaking points in our ToC and we thought we could reduce our uncertainty on this assumption with the help of external evidence
  2. We reviewed evaluations of EA career interventions that are similar to AAC’s work, looking for findings that might be cross-applicable. Most importantly but not exclusively, we looked at the findings from 80,000 Hours’ annual reviews since 2019.
  3. We consulted Animal Charity Evaluators’ review of AAC in 2022, especially looking for crucial aspects that we had not considered and checking how their perspective lines up with ours.

3.2.1  Academic studies on the effect of career services on career plans and capabilities

Due to the limited time available for this research, we decided to focus our efforts in looking for external academic evidence on the plausibility of AAC’s ToC on assumption #13: “Consumers of AAC’s services enhance their career plans and capabilities for work in direct animal advocacy”. Among the three most crucial and uncertain assumptions in the ToC (#1, 13, and 15), this was the assumption we thought could clearly benefit the most from external research. Assumption #1 was already covered by other pieces of evidence (as described in our needs assessment in section 1.1) and #15 seemed highly specific to AAC’s work and a review of external literature did not seem likely to yield highly relevant insights.

As a result, we focused our attention on the question how likely different AAC services are to influence career plans and capabilities of advisees. In line with the ToC, we focused our attention on those services that aimed to influence these outcomes, namely AAC’s career advice (both in generic as well as personal form), online course, and fundraising placement programme. We investigated each kind of service in a quick literature review, using standard tools like Google Scholar or Elicit.

Career advice

In order to evaluate the effects of career advice, we grouped the generic online-content version and the more personal and direct version of AAC’s services together, since some of the best studies we found included different kinds of career advice interventions.

For instance, one random-effects meta-analytical study from 2023 sought to determine the “impacts of career guidance interventions on school students' career-related skills, knowledge and beliefs” (Nargiza et al., 2023), evaluating empirical studies carried out over the previous 10 years, including nine studies involving a total of 1,433 participants. The analysis resulted in a weighted mean effect size of 0.42 (95% confidence interval = 0.19, 0.65; z = 3.61, p < 0.01), which they interpreted as a moderate-to-high effect size, noting a significant difference between the treatment and control conditions at post-treatment. They found that post-test career-related outcomes in students which received career guidance were significantly higher than for students who did not receive career guidance. This suggests that career guidance interventions may provide some modest developmental progression in school-age children and adolescents, “particularly through improving learners' career decidedness and attitudes such as future time perspective” (Nargiza et al., 2023). Notably, the types of interventions varied between studies, but included short to medium term interventions such as a training programme to improve emotional intelligence, a programme aimed to promote learners’ future time perspective and to learn about the current world of work and vocational planning. (Nargiza et al., 2023)

Similarly, another meta analysis of different career choice interventions found that the targets of such interventions scored roughly one third of a standard deviation higher on various outcome measures like career maturity, career decidedness, career decision-making self-efficacy, perceived environmental support, and perceived career barriers (Whiston et al., 2017).

A review by Mackay et al. (2015) found that no single intervention or group of interventions appeared most effective in improving career management skills. However, they identified the five components below which underpinned the interventions that substantially increased effectiveness and can be considered by AAC in their intervention design:

  • The use of narrative/writing
  • The importance of providing a ‘safe’ environment
  • The quality of the adviser-client relationship
  • The need for flexibility in approach; the provision of specialist information and support
  • Clarity on the purpose and aims of action planning

Specifically related to direct, personal career advice, we found some further evidence. Due to a lack of abundant meta analyses or systematic reviews, we decided to include one well-designed non-meta study of career counselling. This study found decreases in career indecision and increases in life satisfaction for recipients of career counselling. “The majority of clients implemented their career choice within a period of one year; some partially implemented it; others changed their career choice, rather successfully; and few people did not demonstrate advancement in either their choice or its implementation during this period of time” (Perdrix, 2012). We also decided to include a meta analysis of the effects of mentoring here, since mentoring and career advice calls share significant similarities. This meta analysis on the effects of mentoring finds benefits on career outcomes at small effect sizes (Allen et al., 2004).

Overall, we find strong evidence that career advice can boost capabilities, career outcomes and plans.

Online Courses

Allen et al. (2006) conducted a meta analysis to compare the test performance of students that engaged in distance versus traditional learning. They found that “distance education course students slightly outperformed traditional students on exams and course grades”. The U.S. Department of Education (2010) reported similar findings in their meta analysis, showing modestly stronger performance of students in online learning versus face-to-face settings. Mathieson (2010) systematically reviewed the results for statistics courses specifically and found student performance to be similar between online and face-to-face learning. Gao et al. (2021) found that exam performance for medical courses in China was higher in participants of massive open online courses versus traditional courses. In sum, all of the relevant meta analyses and systematic reviews we identified in our quick review of the evidence point at the ability of online courses to positively influence student’s capabilities.

When it comes to the effect of online courses on career plans, we could not identify any strong studies in the short time available. The best evidence for this clearly seems to be AAC’s (2023) own evaluation of the effects of their career advice and online course on career-related outcome measures. This was already summarised in section 3.1.2.2 and we can neither positively or negatively update our view based on external evidence here.

Overall, we find good evidence that online courses are an effective tool for learning and can improve participants’ capabilities. The effect on career plans is not clear.

Fundraising placement programme

Inceoglu et al. (2021) conducted a systematic review of quantitative studies that either offered a control group or a longitudinal design, seeking to evaluate the effectiveness of placements for career outcomes. They screened 2394 studies and retained 40 for an in-depth review. They identified that “Placement participation elicits an overall positive (but small) effect on career outcomes”. Most notably, graduates who completed placements found employment more quickly, and students’ perception of their own self-efficacy, knowledge, skills, and attitudes were improved. 

A report by the UK Department of Education (2021) corroborates the general finding that work placements have a small, positive association with career outcomes. Looking at employability programmes and work placements in UK Higher Education, they find that “research looking at students’ own assessments tended to find almost ubiquitous evidence of perceived skill development”. Indeed, they conclude that even when statistical techniques are employed to account for selection effects from ability or motivation, “a positive, albeit possibly smaller, wage return to work placements is seen [...], as well as a positive impact on employment outcomes such as the likelihood of being invited to interview”. However they also note several concerns with the methodology and sparsity of evidence available in this field. In particular, they identify that “even in the literature on opportunities, costs and benefits for students or graduates, the research evidence tended to be piecemeal rather than comprehensive.” Further, they note that skill development does not always translate into improved labour outcomes, and posit several explanations for this, such as that not all work placements develop skills equally and that work placements are associated with improved career outcomes as they serve as signals to employers rather than necessarily increasing skills.

Another systematic review, focused on international internships and skill development, found that in 9 out of 49 studies reviewed, career decision-management was identified as a skill gained through participation in international internships by students in higher education (Di Pietro, 2022).

Gillespie et al. (2020) also found positive relationships between internship participation and career development measures (including professional development, career adaptability, career commitment, and career exploration) and learning outcome measures (such as GPA and skill development) in their review. They concluded that the positive effects of internship participation seem greater from voluntary than for compulsory internships and that the positive effects diminish over time. Further, they corroborate the suggestion of the aforementioned studies, that the role of internships is as a signal that students acquired greater skills, knowledge, and productivity.

Overall, we found reasonably strong evidence of a small to moderate positive association between internship or work placement completion and career outcomes, measured through a range of factors including skill development, self-perception, employment outcomes, and career adaptability. However, there is also a suggestion that this association is explained best by the signalling hypothesis, that internships serve as a signal of skills to employers, and that this may not necessarily mean capabilities themselves are significantly improved. Despite this uncertainty, it seems plausible that such placements improve capabilities and career outcomes. It should be noted that the majority of studies concern students in higher education, which AAC’s programme was not limited to. Further, skill development may be higher in effectively designed fundraising placements which AAC’s programme provides than at the baseline for such placements. Nevertheless, this provides enough collective evidence that placements tend to have positive effects upon capabilities and career plans.

Overall, the evidence for the effect of placements and internships on capabilities and career plans seems even stronger than for the other services. This is in line with the finding in section 3.1.2.2 that the work placement programme is a high-quality and high-effort service.

Summary

In sum, we find good evidence for assumption #13 of the ToC to hold. If properly implemented, AAC’s career advice, online course, and fundraising programme should improve participants’ career plans and outcomes as well as capabilities. This matches with the internal evaluation evidence collected by AAC described in section 3.1.2.2.

3.2.2  Evidence from similar EA programmes

On their “About” page, AAC cite 80,000 Hours (80K) as a successful example of an organisation that provides career advice and addresses talent bottlenecks in the adjacent effective altruism community. They suggest that similar services focused specifically on animal issues could have similarly positive effects. (Animal Advocacy Careers, 2019) We agree that evidence from highly related programmes is an important form of evidence for us to consider here. While it might be less rigorous than the academic studies cited above, this evidence is more directly applicable to the case of AAC and can thus give more practical insights.

80,000 Hours

When looking at programmes that are similar to AAC’s and how they can inform our perspective on AAC’s work, 80,000 Hours indeed stands out.

As 80K started already in 2011 (80,000 Hours, n.d.), they have been able to review and refine their services over a longer time span than AAC. For instance, they already did surveys in 2014 that seem highly insightful into the kind of impact that career advice services can have. In these surveys, they found that 63 out of 206 respondents said that engagement with 80K had changed their career plans. Other sources apart from their surveys informed them of another forty people that had changed plans because of them. These career changes were based on multiple different 80K services like 1-1 advice and events, which all seemed impactful. Roughly one third of plan changes were the result of just reading 80K’s online content, showing that online content alone can be impactful, without deeper engagement levels (like direct, personal advice). In addition to plan changes, 80K also found that their services successfully introduced people to the EA community and changed people’s attitudes towards career. (80,000 Hours, 2014)

Later reviews by 80K found that their initial impact estimates were probably overly optimistic and had to be corrected downwards. In 2019, they wrote the following:

“In past years, we were overly credulous when the people who made plan changes claimed we permanently changed the trajectory of their careers and our investigations into these claims were insufficiently skeptical, thoughtful and thorough. This led us to overestimate our impact, especially on those people who already had some ties to the EA community, because there are already other influences pushing in the same direction. The team has become substantially less likely to take claims about our impact at face value, which we think is reflected in the new system we’re developing for evaluating our impact.” (80,000 Hours, 2019)

80K’s work generally stresses that tracking the impact on career plans is very hard, especially because such changes occur over long periods of time. To account for this, 80K uses qualitative insights as an additional perspective in their evaluations. (80,000 Hours, 2019)

80K’s reviews in later years still showed a positive impact of their work. However, there are some negative aspects or doubts that we need to highlight here. First, it seems that 80K’s work has hit diminishing returns, as their services have grown over the years (80,000 Hours, 2020). Second, 80K found its job board to be less cost-effective than other services and considered cutting the service back or spinning it off. They decided to continue running it, as it seems like a low-effort resource that the EA community should have at its disposal. However, they also decided against investing further into this service and kept it running at low capacity. (80,000 Hours, 2019, 2020) Third, 80K decided to pause its headhunting service in 2022, focusing more on career advice. The reasons for this seem to have been mostly administrative (i.e. not finding a good person to lead this aspect of their work) and not related to the service’s effectiveness. Fourth, 80K found that their content made some of their readers feel sad/stressed/demoralised, as they came away feeling that they did not have what it takes to make a meaningful contribution (80,000 Hours, 2020). Fifth, the collapse of FTX and the case of Sam Bankman-Fried made 80K aware of other potentially negative effects of their work, causing them to update some of their advice. Their decision to focus more on doing research and improving their advice in 2023 also seems tightly connected to these developments. (80,000 Hours, 2022).

These experiences seem highly relevant for our assessment of AAC’s programmes and their (potential) impact. 80K generally offers quite similar services, just at a larger scale and with a broader focus, and can thus act as a good comparison. Below we describe the key takeaways from our review of 80K and how they update our perspective:

  • Overall, 80K’s success in a highly similar field updates us positively on the likelihood of impact and effectiveness of AAC’s programmes. Particularly, the general online career resources and the direct, personal advice should be effective in changing people’s career plans. 80K’s experience with the job board seems less promising, but it still seems like a service worth offering. This leads us to positively update our perspective on assumptions #2 and 3, and to a lesser extent #10, 11, 13, and 14.
  • 80K’s initial overestimation of their impact highlights why counterfactuals need to be taken seriously when evaluating impact. As described in section 3.1.1.2, we think that AAC has properly incorporated counterfactual considerations into their approach, adjusting the placements they influenced for importance and counterfactuals. While counterfactuals are hard to account for, AAC’s approach seems sufficiently rigorous. The fact that 80K was and is also struggling with their M&E efforts and find it hard to assess their own impact shows how difficult such an exercise is in the realm of meta interventions like AAC’s.
  • 80K’s decision to pause its headhunting services seems different from that of AAC to suspend their recruitment service. While 80K’s reasons were mostly operational/administrative, AAC had concerns about the effectiveness of the programme. It still seems notable that both organisations experienced difficulties with this approach, making us sceptical of the value of recruitment services. This affects assumption #15, as recruitment services are aimed at directly increasing the availability of good talent in the movement.
  • AAC needs to watch out for diminishing returns in the services they provide. This seems like a natural development in many fields and should keep AAC vigilant in their assessment of their own programmes and in making strategic decisions.
  • There are significant potential negative effects to giving wrong, misleading, or otherwise harmful career advice. On the one hand, AAC needs to mind the potential of their content to alienate its consumers. On the other hand, they should stress to their advisees’ the importance of wider, long-term consequences of their actions, especially when it comes to outsized risk taking and unethical behaviour. These concerns caution us in our assessment and should be actively considered by AAC. They slightly negatively update our view on assumption #1, as well as on assumptions #15 and 20, as it seems more uncertain that AAC can find the most promising careers in animal advocacy and give correct advice that will lead to positive changes in people’s career paths.

Centre for Effective Altruism

Apart from 80,000 Hours, there are some other programmes within EA focused on careers and movement building that bear some similarity to some of AAC’s work. For instance, the Centre for Effective Altruism is trying to grow the effective altruism movement by running fellowships and virtual programmes, supporting university groups, organising conferences and retreats, and other services. We checked some of their reporting to see whether it can yield relevant insights for our evaluation of AAC.

However, most of the information we found did not prove to be too helpful. While they have a public data dashboard and regularly posts updates about their work on their blog (Centre for Effective Altruism 2021, 2023), almost all of the data the Centre for Effective Altruism reports on seems to focus on activities and outputs. For example, they list the number of attendees of retreats and EA Global conferences, the number of university groups supported via advice and grants, and the number of participants in fellowships and virtual programmes. They do report on some more advanced measures like people’s likelihood to recommend retreats and conferences, as well as completion rates for their fellowships and virtual programmes. Philip Hall Andersen’s (2022) review of introductory EA courses also mostly focuses on monitoring and process evaluation, but does not look at the further effects on career choices.

We did find one EA Forum post (2019) on the Centre for Effective Altruism’s work that contained some useful information. Evaluating 1-1 meetings they organised for participants in EA virtual programmes, they found that such meetings generally seem valuable, but less scalable and more time-consuming than other services. Especially valuable seem those 1-1s focused on careers and networking, with mentors that are experienced in a specific cause area (e.g. animal welfare), sociable, and very knowledgeable. Mid-career professionals are mentioned as the most promising target group for such 1-1s. The organisers think that the meetings can be impactful when it comes to influencing people’s career paths. All of these findings are tentative and do not seem based on an extremely rigorous evaluation. They should thus be taken with caution, but can provide a weak form of evidence for our review.

Below we summarise our key takeaways from the review of the Centre of Effective Altruism and how they update our perspective

  • Most of the data we found is not comprehensive enough and too dependent on the specific implementation of CEA’s programmes such that it cannot be used to inform our view of AAC’s work.
  • The findings from evaluating 1-1s seem applicable to AAC’s work and match some of the findings from their evaluation. Specifically, they positively update us on assumption #3 (the ability to run a well-received direct career advice programme) and, to a lesser extent, #10, 11, and 13 (changes in career plans based on AAC’s activities), showing that personal meetings to discuss careers can be a valuable service to the community.

Animal-focused organisations

Further relevant external evidence could come from other capacity-building organisations in the animal advocacy movement. Especially career-oriented services like the talent database offered by the Good Food Institute or Tälist’s services could be investigated. Due to the limited time available for this report, we decided not to pursue these paths here though. Also, Tälist might be too young (they started in 2022) to already have a good understanding of the impact of their work.

Summary

In sum, we find highly relevant evidence from similar programmes within the EA movement. The overwhelming majority of evidence updates us positively on a variety of assumptions in the ToC. However, we also found some reasons for caution that need to be strongly considered by AAC.

3.2.3  2022 Animal Charity Evaluators review

In 2022, Animal Charity Evaluators (ACE) evaluated AAC in order to determine whether they should be recommended to donors as one of their top or standout charities. ACE’s review was overall very positive but did not end up recommending AAC because other charities scored higher on the kinds of programmes they pursue and their cost-effectiveness. (Animal Charity Evaluators, 2022)

ACE thinks that AAC’s strategic priorities are important ones, targeting high-priority countries and focusing on high-priority outcomes and interventions. Capacity building is seen as a neglected but important area and the impact of research is considered promising, especially in the long term. The online course, fundraising placement programme, and job board were found to be the most cost-effective of AAC’s services, while the recruitment service scored lowest. All programmes scored moderate to high in terms of cost-effectiveness. It is important to note that the review did not seem to include AAC’s written career advice, mailing list, and inclusive hiring workshops. (Animal Charity Evaluators, 2022)

Overall, these findings provide the following updates to our view of AAC’s work:

  • The review by ACE does not provide much significant new information that we had not already gathered in previous sections of this evidence review. The overall picture of AAC’s programmes and organisation is very positive, which matches our perspective thus far.
  • The recruitment services offered by AAC are an issue to monitor, as they seemed least cost effective to ACE and were already restructured by AAC (as described in section 3.1). Investigating the effects of AAC’s top candidate database (the new implementation of recruitment services) should be an evaluation priority going forward.

3.3  What have we learned and not learned?

The evidence we have collected in this section gives us a much better understanding of AAC’s work and impact. In the table below, we summarise the assumptions from the ToC described in section 2 and how we update our views on each of them based on this evidence review. The colours in the ‘Assumption’ column match those given in section 2.2, indicating our levels of uncertainty around the assumptions, while the colours in the ‘Update’ column represent how the different factors we identified update our view. We naturally weigh strong, internal, or case-specific evidence more heavily than weak, external, or general evidence. The different shades of red and green in the ‘Update’ column account for this. We then assign a final uncertainty score from 1 (low uncertainty) to 5 (high uncertainty).

This overview illustrates that the evidence review positively updates us on most assumptions in the ToC and that we generally have few significant uncertainties.

Below we list the most important remaining uncertainties and our perspective on them:

  • To what extent can AAC make sure that the services they provide do not have negative externalities by pushing people into paths that are not the best option for them, causing anxiety over career decisions, or causing overall harm to the movement?
    • This seems hard to guarantee. The best way to avoid negative externalities is probably to do rigorous research into the best career paths and carefully consider all options. Specifically monitoring potential negative effects could also be helpful.
  • Should AAC continue to pursue recruitment services in some form or another, given that previous experiences with these services do not seem too promising?
    • AAC’s leadership has shared with us that there is a strong demand for these services from the organisations in their network. Recruitment services also seem highly demanded in the for-profit sector, so they should be helpful in the nonprofit sector as well. It might just be about finding out which kind of service works best. We remain somewhat sceptical about this and think this needs to be monitored closely, as it might simply be that there is no recruitment service that can be as cost effective as AAC’s other services.

We will summarise these and all of our other recommendations for AAC in section 7. Before we do that however, we first need to have a more detailed look at the cost-effectiveness of AAC’s programmes in the next section, the health of the organisation as a whole in section 5, as well as their future plans and room for more funding in section 6.

4.2 Evaluation of AAC’s methodology

Given the limited time available for this section of the report, we determined that we would be unable to produce a higher quality metric to measure impact than AAC’s own ICAPs. We therefore decided to instead examine AAC’s methodology and calculations in depth and make recommendations for how they could be improved. First, in section 4.2.1, we look at how AAC estimates the ICAPs generated by a given placement and how robust these estimates are. We also make recommendations for how this could be improved. Second, in section 4.2.2, we analyse the calculation underlying the monetary value of one ICAP and make recommendations for how it could be made more robust.

4.2.1  ICAP estimates per placement

Calibration of counterfactual estimates

In order to estimate the ICAPs generated by a certain placement, AAC follows three steps:

  1. Identifying the distribution of impact AAC had upon the participant’s placement over each service engaged with by the participant
  2. Identifying the importance of a placement to the movement by assigning an estimated multiplier for the importance of their organisation, relative to the average EAA organisation
  3. Identifying the counterfactual impact that AAC had on this placement by estimating the probability of the individual not placing a role within the movement within the next five years

In order to test the validity of AAC’s importance judgments (step #2 above), AAC have sought independent judgement calibration from other organisations.

However, the counterfactual judgments (step #3) have not been tested. Therefore, in order to test the validity of these judgments, one of us (Aashish) performed a calibration and sensitivity analysis on the values assigned for the estimated probability of the individual not placing a role within the movement within the next five years.

The methodology we employed was the following:

  1. Selected 5 participants at random
  2. Outlined a rubric for evaluating the counterfactual impact AAC had on their placement
  3. Read the interview transcripts that AAC conducted with them and marked them against this rubric
  4. Assigned a score
  5. Compared scores to AAC’s score

The results of this exercise can be seen in the table below. For the sake of confidentiality, no identifying information about the participants will be provided.

Notably, there was a low disparity between our scores and AAC’s scores. This provides some evidence for the robustness of AAC’s estimates. However, given our limited knowledge of the animal advocacy job space, we would not over-index on our own estimates of the probability of the individual not placing a role within the movement within the next five years. 

We recommend that AAC solicit feedback from more experienced people to calibrate their judgements. In addition, AAC currently does not have a clear rubric or framework for coming to well calibrated estimates. This may lead to some margin of error or variation in scores. As described above, we created a simple rubric for assigning our scores in this calibration exercise. We recommend that AAC develop something similar for their own use. Below, we list the factors used in our calibration, which can serve as inspiration and starting point for AAC to build upon.

  • Motivation
    • Was the participant interested in working in animal advocacy?
  • Initiative
    • Have they taken any previous steps to improve their fit for jobs?
    • Have they taken any previous steps to apply for jobs?
    • Did the AAC programme they engaged with increase their motivation to find a job?
  • Competence
    • Did they possess a relevant skill set to provide value to an organisation within the movement?
    • Did they possess relevant experience with EAA or the job-type they sought?
    • Did the AAC programme they engaged with increase their skill set?
  • Awareness
    • Did they have the relevant network and/or awareness of jobs within the EAA space without AAC?
    • Did the AAC programme they engaged with increase their awareness of opportunities?

Sensitivity analysis on counterfactual estimates

Given that the scores we arrived at differed somewhat from those given by AAC, it is important to determine how significant variation in this metric would be upon the final impact and cost effectiveness estimates. Therefore, we conducted a sensitivity analysis on this metric, adjusting all estimates for counterfactual impact since the beginning of ACE’s impact evaluation.

The table below outlines the sensitivity analysis performed, determining the effect of varying the counterfactual judgement score upon the overall impact and cost effectiveness of AAC’s total activities. For a sensitivity analysis by programme, see appendix A (in the full PDF report). 

This demonstrates that very small variation in the counterfactual judgements that are central to calculating the number of ICAPs generated per placement can result in moderately large changes in the total cost-effectiveness of the organisation. This highlights the importance of systematising the values assigned to this metric.   

As aforementioned, given these results we recommend that AAC take efforts to systematise their counterfactual judgement estimations. The following steps seem promising to us:

  1. Use confidence intervals rather than point estimates:
    Currently, two employees of AAC provide point estimates for this metric. To improve robustness and increase reasoning transparency, we suggest that they provide a 90% confidence interval, and take the average of the overlap between these intervals. Our prior is that using ranges rather than point estimates increases the accuracy of the judgement, as one can consider what they believe the upper and lower bound to be, and this also allows for the level of uncertainty and precision to be conveyed. 
  2. Develop a rubric:
    A rubric or framework for coming to these judgements is critical, in order to ensure that this process is systematic and controlled.
  3. Identify examples of individual cases where the confidence is in the estimate is high for the calibration of scores
  4. Determine base rates, upper and lower bounds:
    AAC should determine the extent to which different factors tend to contribute to job placement. Determining the base rate for different broad categories of individuals to land placements in the movement, based on key factors like experience, skill, motivation and awareness, may help to calibrate estimates. Further, determining the expected upper and lower bounds for the probability of any person to land a placements in the EAA movement regardless of the aforementioned factors, would improve judgements at the extremes.

4.2.2  The monetary value of an ICAP

Assuming that ICAP estimates per placement are relatively robust (which they seem to be based on our analysis above and which they might be even more so in the future if our recommendations are implemented), the cost effectiveness estimates of AAC’s work might still be mistaken, if the monetary value assigned to an ICAP is off.

ICAPs are calculated based on a multiplicative model and represent a monetary equivalent of value added to the movement as a result of AAC’s programmes. AAC uses the following formula:

1 ICAP = Average number of years the candidate will continue working in the movement * Average salary of a candidate * Percentage better the candidate is than the next best candidate

For each ICAP, AAC estimates an addition of  USD 37,500 to the movement. This is based on the assumption that each placement is 10% better than the next best candidate and will continue working in the movement for 7.5 years, with an average salary of  USD 50,000 annually. AAC has also added a multiplier for cases where organisations think that the placement was above or below the 10% assumption, to adjust this value.

From our interview with AAC, we understood that the assumption of the number of years a new placement will stay in the movement is a conservative estimate, and is not based on any particular dataset. Given the degree of variation there may be in this value, we performed a sensitivity analysis to determine how changes in this value would impact the total value of one ICAP in the table below. 

The analysis shows that the value generated per ICAP varies drastically, if assumptions about the duration of impact change.

Based on our conversations with AAC, we understand that AAC’s estimate of USD 37,500 per ICAP might err on the conservative side, as other organisations (like 80,000 Hours) use higher monetary values in their evaluations. As such, it seems unlikely that AAC is grossly overestimating its impact.

Nevertheless, it seems highly beneficial for AAC to enhance the foundations that their ICAP estimate is built on. To increase the certainty around the assumption of the number of years an individual stays in the movement, we propose AAC use existing data or collect novel data, to build a probability distribution for this metric that represents the state of the movement. The weighted average from this can be taken, to more robustly determine the average number of years a new placement stays in the movement. This may also be updated periodically, such as every five years or at points where it becomes clear that career norms in the movement have changed and that the previous value no longer holds.

5 Organisational health and transparency

Apart from AAC’s specific programmes and their effectiveness, we also decided to include a brief analysis of the organisation as a whole. In this section, we will first provide our perspective on AAC’s organisational health (section 5.1) and then on their transparency in communication and data sharing (section 5.2). Overall, AAC’s organisational health seems strong. In their review of AAC, Animal Charity Evaluators (2022) did not detect any reason for concern when it comes to AAC’s leadership and culture.
